Title: Will our fascination with "evil" never cease?
Review:
Detective Lt. William Somerset (Morgan Freeman) is about to retire. He is teamed up with a young new detective David Mills (Brad Pitt). Together they try to find a serial killer who uses the seven deadly sins as his M.O. Meanwhile Mills' wife Tracy (Gwyneth Paltrow) fears for her husband's life and is very depressed.

Dark and depressing but just fascinating. Director David Fincher shots the entire film in dim light and shoves the victims mutilated bodies in our face. The grimness of the tone wears you down but that's appropriate considering the subject matter. No humor either. It all leads to a truly harrowing ending. There was supposed to be a happy ending but they (wisely) chose not to do it. Freeman and Pitt work very well together and both give excellent performances. I even thought Paltrow (who I hate) was good! Kevin Spacey is very good too in a small role.

If you have trouble with blood, gore and disturbing subject matter stay far away from this movie. But if you can handle that, watch this one. It's depressing and unpleasant but riveting.

Title: a new kind of thriller
Review:
i thought that this was and excellent movie. David Fincher does an amazing job at holding your attention with horrific but yet cultivating scenes. And the combo of Brad Pitt and Morgan Freeman is exhilarating i rated this movie a ten easily. The point of it is not to scare but to teach the audience that there are killers out there with the intent to kill gruesomely for the benefit of making a name for themselves. Kevin Spacey who plays the murder in this film does an amazing job. He has to get the point across to the audience that he is a highly intelligent person but at the same time also insane. This movie really gives us a first hand look at the darker more menacing side of crime mysterious.

Title: spacey in seven
Review:
This is to Gardenwriter.

The reason Kevin Spacey's name is not in the opening credits is because he asked to be uncredited on purpose. This was to keep his character a secret, ambiguous. If people knew Spacey was in it then they would have known that he was John Doe from the very beginning. So that is why. Spacey wouldn't take the role if they had put his name in the opening credits. I think more movies should do this. It is a very smart way of not giving away everything in the movie. Gary Oldman did the same thing in Hannibal, so people would look at the character and not Gary Oldman playing the character.

Title: A dark, gripping thriller which saves it's most shocking revelations for the final scenes.
Review:
Detective Lt. William Somerset (Morgan Freeman) is about to retire. He is teamed up with a young new detective David Mills (Brad Pitt). Together they try to find a serial killer who uses the seven deadly sins as his M.O. Meanwhile Mills' wife Tracy (Gwyneth Paltrow) fears for her husband's life and is very depressed.

Dark and depressing but just fascinating. Director David Fincher shots the entire film in dim light and shoves the victims mutilated bodies in our face. The grimness of the tone wears you down but that's appropriate considering the subject matter. No humor either. It all leads to a truly harrowing ending. There was supposed to be a happy ending but they (wisely) chose not to do it. Freeman and Pitt work very well together and both give excellent performances. I even thought Paltrow (who I hate) was good! Kevin Spacey is very good too in a small role.

If you have trouble with blood, gore and disturbing subject matter stay far away from this movie. But if you can handle that, watch this one. It's depressing and unpleasant but riveting.

Title: Se7en has a wild storyline, leading to a wild time.
Review:
This movie has so much effort and care put into it. You can see this even in the first couple scenes, as the character development and the story already begin to take place. As the movie progresses, it shows even more development and imagination. The dark twists and turns, Brad Pitt's believable performance as a less mature, more lively character, differentiating from Morgan Freedman's cold-hearted cop who is done with all of it. David Fincher really shows off what he can do with this movie, leading to a genre-changing film.

Title: An aesthetic of its own
Review:
That certain noir feel, tweaked so perfectly, keeps all the richness of noir and loses the period specific dialog that makes classic noir films often feel like cultural artifacts rather than immediately engaging stories that entertain on their own intrinsic merits. Death by sin: gluttonous guy eats too much, lustful guy sexes one too many times, and so on and so on. It's noir without being simply a movie about movies, without simply being an homage to other moviesit stands on its own, it has its own aesthetic, it's just that that aesthetic captures the spirit of luxurious mystery that is associated by film lovers with film noir. Death by sin: gluttonous guy eats too much, lustful guy sexes one too many times, and so on and so on.

Title: Love It!!
Review:
After watching it again on DVD for about the 20th time I was amazed by how much this film still grabs me - genuinely think that its my favourite movie ever....pure absolute class.

I know thats a bold statement but I really think it is - I have never watched a film so many times and been able to completely lose myself it it like this film - normally the only films I can watch over and over again are comedies.

The lead acts are so good,and the action extremely clever not a film for the faint hearted though... me missus finds parts of the film disgusting (which I think makes me like the film even more) and don't go expecting a warm, fuzzy feeling at the end...be prepared!

Title: A masterpiece of the human mind.
Review:
This is not a movie. This is not a 2 hour and some odd minutes vaunt into some fairy land where you leave the theater smiling, discussing character development and costume design.

Rather, SE7EN is dark and rainy. It shows us what our secrets look like; it exemplifies the mysteries behind what we all think but never dare whisper in even the most intimate company. Anyone intelligent enough to appreciate such images and emotions will revere SE7EN as a work of art. Only the most immature viewers, blinded by images of death and darkness, will not understand what SE7EN is. SE7EN is what life is.

Title: I found myself shocked yet totally engrossed
Review:
David Fincher. An auteur? Judging by films such as Alien3, the Game and Fight Club you might be forgiven for thinking so but it's Se7en that really stands out. Dark, disturbing and dangerously addictive. This film has all the ingredients of a thought provoking, highly entertaining film and the tried and tested old cop/young cop plot is given a complete and refreshing overhaul.

The menacing idea behind the film is second to the none and the addition of great performances by Freeman (on top form as the old cop) and Pitt (proving he can act) only add to the overall quality.

Includes one of the most memorable scenes in film this decade where John Doe utters the words, "Detective. Detective. DETECTIVE"!

Prepare yourself though, for the ending that ultimately leaves a very long lasting impression on you. The twist will throw you so far off course it will take several viewings for it all to sink in.

This is how films should be made. David Fincher is a directing hero. Freeman and Pitt are perfect in their roles. Se7en is a landmark for detective thrillers. Watch it!

Title: Well worth a few hours of your time
Review:
This film is perhaps one of the most intriguing, thought-provoking movies in a long while. The style by which David Fincher presents this movie is perhaps comparable to the late Alfred Hitchcock, an achievement not easily gained. Morgan Freeman delivers a stellar performance as a police officer on the brink of retirement only to be pulled back into the life he is trying to escape by a psychopathic maniac. Brad Pitt brings to the screen the mentality of a rookie cop dead-set on solving the case that just happened to fall in his lap. Pitt somewhat lacks in experience compared to Freeman and it is evident in the movie, but hats off to his attempt to keep on the same playing field as Freeman. I believe that David Fincher wanted the identity of the murderer to remain concealed, otherwise this person would have been listed in the opening credits and on the movie poster, so I will end on that note. This movie is well worth $20 to own, let alone worth a few hour of your time. A must see.

Title: bleak, excellent serial killer drama
Review:
Brad Pitt in the performance of his career is excellent as a detective teamed with Morgan Freeman, both men at opposite ends of there lives. This is a chilling and graphic thriller with as much style as substance. The killer, when revealed is very surprising, though you have probably seen it. David Fincher brings gritty realism to the tale of an intelligent maniac basing horrific killings on the seven deadly sins. A smart screenplay and surprising in-sight on humanity and our downward spiral makes for a thoroughly involving and bleak motion picture. You can't find a film like it.

Title: Playing on our own apathy?
Review:
Seven was vaguely entertaining and fabulously well filmed, but marred by a general lack of character development. While the film does well to create an oppressive aura over the unnamed city, I found that I really couldn't care less about the characters, which upon first viewing I saw as a major fault.

On the second viewing, I felt a little more kindly toward the movie. As one of the major themes of the story and the primary motivation of John Doe's killings is the apathy of modern society -that no one cares about anyone else- I wondered if David Fincher was trying to trick us into feeling the same way?

Was I deliberately not supposed to feel for the characters, in order to have some 'feeling' (albeit through a strange agent) shocked into me at the end? I'm not sure. Fincher has proved himself an excellent, intelligent filmmaker, but I'm still unsure of whether to offer him the benefit of the doubt in the case of Seven.

6/10.

Title: Special Edition Version (DVD): Se7enth Heaven.
Review:
This movie's title sequence alone has changed the film and television mediums forever. Even if you aren't a film buff, you will immediately recognize this after seeing this beautifully creepy, acid-washed and frantic collage of images. Fincher's stylistic use of framing, lighting, and choice of cinematographer creates a mood that sinks like a brick to the pit of your stomach.

If I were to choose a genre movie that could definetley top Johnathan Demme's "The Silence of the Lambs", this would be the one. Brad Pitt, Morgan Freeman and Gwenyth Paltrow are dead-on portraying each of their characters; respectively: a detective who has requested a transfer to the non-specific city's seedier side, a veteran detective who is set to retire in seven days, and a wife who is entirely reluctant about moving to this inner-city. The events which unfold, wrap these characters into a series of situations where no viewer will guess the horrifying ending until it is fully set in motion.

Spacey alone deserves a separate paragraph. If you thought Hannibal was devious and witty (and he is), check out Mr. Spacey as John Doe. His subtle portrayal is in contrast to Mr. Hopkin's over-the-top, almost campy Hannibal Lector. Kevin Spacey sets the "creep-factor" to 10 in his vision of a truly sadistic serial killer.

Do yourself a favor, even if you aren't a noir or horror fan. See this movie, because there are a myriad of reasons to appreciate what Fincher has created. If you think you won't get into the story because this, at first glance, appears to be a glorified horror movie, you will be cheating yourself out an incredible film experience.

Title: The most thought-provoking and gripping fiction of ancients
Review:
I had really liked this movie before I watched it beacuse of its forceful cast. Morgan Freeman and Brad Pitt who are the most famous actors in the world are taking part together. Therefore, in my opinion, there shouldn't be any prejudice about movie in your mind.

It was a masterpiece of ancient movie fictions owing to its well-written, gripping, disturbing and intresting scenario. The movie is about metaphorically seven sins, two detective and a serial killer. The seven sins are explained as people's common behaviors such as being greedy and being arrogant . In the scenerio, The murder kills people and leaves traces behind himself about those ''seven sins'' before he leaves from each homicide areas. Then detectives start to follow the case.

From my perspective, the director of this movie confronts us with our own common behaviours and enforces us to think which kind of ''sin'' we generally have. Therefore, movie's main theme was processed well and ideas were completely understandable. Other than, It had extraordinary crime scenes and fascinating dialogues between two detectives so nothing was boring.

Title: Excellent movie... Brad Pitt overrated
Review:
I loved Se7en. Engrossing, mysterious plot that you can read about in other reviews. It's been said enough how excellent this movie is, but I don't remember reading anything about Brad Pitt's performance being overrated so I figured I'd share my thoughts. Having seen Fight Club before watching any earlier Pitt movies, I was mostly disappointed with Brad's performances (except for a few). His casual conversations and such in Se7en seemed unique to Pitt (a couple of head scratches, looking around a lot, very confident dialogue, etc.), but the emotionally intense scenes (especially the final scene), which are extremely important, seemed very awkward and unrealistic given the circumstances of the plot's brutal context. My opinion of Brad Pitt's less than desirable performance in Se7en didn't ruin the movie for me, but without the awkwardness delivered in those crucial emotional scenes, this movie would be a flawless film.

Title: Masterful
Review:
Se7en is a chilling, concise, psychological thriller. Somerset (Freeman) and Mills (Pitt)are two detectives trying to track down a serial killer. The movie's simplicity is what makes it so great. There are some wonderful contrasts made between the characters and settings throughout this movie that add to film's mystique. The detectives encounter a variety of interesting, colorful characters that go well with the shocking nature of the different killings that occur.

If you haven't seen this film, the ending will leave you speechless.

Be sure to check out the DVD platinum edition that contains several special features including two full-lenght commentaries with the stars and producers.

One of the best. *****

Title: Se7en has to be considered one of the best horror and suspense movies ever
Review:
Seven is a movie starring for Morgan Freeman and Brad Pitt, a couple of geniuses of the acting in the shoes of the investigators William Sommerset and David Mills, respectively. The movie is classified as a suspense movie, because it unfolds through around to a serie of crimes which started to committed by a serial killer without any cause, however, each of one of the victims were represented by each of one of the seven deadly sins, reminder how we know that seven sins are the causes of any other perversions of the human, according to the Christian religión. The movie also is acclaimed because it takes us for many possible emotions from some smiles to the frightening, the astonishing and more than anything to the reflexión about what it's wrong and what it's well, according the viewpoint and what it implies the consequences of a lot of the human behaviors.

The film could be leave nuisance, because isn't the casual end of a crime movie where always the good guy wins and the bad guy lost or where the good guy is who leave the reflexión. Also, the movie is too chritic and we make us think in the true repentance for the wrong done or just an contrition act, where the regret is not for loving god but it's for what the person can lost. Another part about the movie is about the murderer, a methodic and specially patiance man, who has most the planned things and he knows that even in the end of their lifes, the humans ever ends falling into the life's perversions. Title: a classic of the horror, thriller genre
Review: this movie easily ranks in my top 10 of all time. for one thing, the cast was brillant. Brad Pitt did a wonderful job as the young, eneregic cop thats hot on the trail of the killer. Morgan freeman also gave a strong performance as the "wise old owl" cop so to say. gwyneth paltrow also had a strong preformance in the limited screen time. kevin spacey was the key to this film. very seldom does spacey not speak a line that is well thought out and has meaning to it. he makes you feel his character. the question through the movie is whether John doe, the killer, is insane or if he's a normal guy like you and me. at one point david mills (Brad Pitt) asks John doe, " do you wake up in the morning and say, wow its amazing how f***in crazy i really am" to which Doe answers, "it makes you feel comfortable to label me as crazy, doesnt it" and mills replies with a simple, " yes very comfortable". i thought this was a brillant scene as you makes you think that maybe this killer isnt insane, maybe he just wants to prove a point. he could be as normal as you and me but he believes in something so strongly that he's willing to kill and be killed for others to "see" it. i also thought this movie had ties to 8 millimeter. in 8 millimeter the killer or killers were normal people, they killed because they liked it and because they could. i think is kind of the same thing in seven. although John doe proclaims he's a "chosen one" and he does not want to kill, he proclaims he is not insane, no one molested him as a child, no one abused him. overall this is just a brillant film. the mood set in this film is perfect. almost every scene involves rain which leaves a dark, depressing mood which is perfect for the plot. the murders are detailed and well thought out. i would certainly recommend this movie to anyone who loves horror and others who want to see a true bred classic.

I recommend this movie for its dark and rich atmosphere.

Title: The growing number
Review:
We examine the growing number of studies of survey respondents' global self-ratings of health as predictors of mortality in longitudinal studies of representative community samples. Twenty-seven studies in U. S. and international journals show impressively consistent findings. Global self-rated health is an independent predictor of mortality in nearly all of the studies, despite the inclusion of numerous specific health status indicators and other relevant covariates known to predict mortality. We summarize and review these studies, consider various interpretations which could account for the association, and suggest several approaches to the next stage of research in this field.

Title: With this movie, I started watching top movies
Review:
Detective Lt. William Somerset (Morgan Freeman) is about to retire. He is teamed up with a young new detective David Mills (Brad Pitt). Together they try to find a serial killer who uses the seven deadly sins as his M.O. Meanwhile Mills' wife Tracy (Gwyneth Paltrow) fears for her husband's life and is very depressed.

Dark and depressing but just fascinating. Director David Fincher shots the entire film in dim light and shoves the victims mutilated bodies in our face. The grimness of the tone wears you down but that's appropriate considering the subject matter. No humor either. It all leads to a truly harrowing ending. There was supposed to be a happy ending but they (wisely) chose not to do it. Freeman and Pitt work very well together and both give excellent performances. I even thought Paltrow (who I hate) was good! Kevin Spacey is very good too in a small role.

If you have trouble with blood, gore and disturbing subject matter stay far away from this movie. But if you can handle that, watch this one. It's depressing and unpleasant but riveting.

Title: Over The Top DVD Masterpeice
Review:
I wont bore you with ANOTHER summary (why do amateur film reviewers feel the need to summarize the whole damn movie?) but i WILL say that Se7en is one of the top thrillers I have ever viewed with and incredible crescendo of intensity that builds to a climax that literally had me digging my fingers into my legs and freaking out. And I am usually THAT GUY who can guess the entire plot of a flick after the first 3 minutes. Or at least think I can.

Brad Pitt and Morgan Freeman are GREAT as the two detectives on the hunt for (and seemingly always three steps behind) a serial murderer and their performances really defy the cookie cutter "he's the grizzled veteran with one month to go and he's the young triggerhappy punk cop" roles. Great dialogue and compellingly gruesome yet clever and....intelligent evil going on.

Between Fight Club and Se7en, David Fincher has really put a dent in my top 20 alltime fave flicks and I give it my top rating.

ASIDE: Here's a DVD that really gives you some juicy extra features...storyboards, alternate endings with director's commentary, etc. I cant WAIT to watch it tonight with the Pitt, Freeman, and Fincher commentary...

GET IT.

Title: The most original movie in years.
Review: The title of the film 'Seven' is very exact and dominating in the telling of its story. Seven murders take place in the time of seven days, each death based on one of the seven deadly sins. The climax to the film also takes place at 7.07am. So the film cleverly bases its structure on the film's title. The film is in the genre of a neo-noir thriller. It gains its category through the dark techniques used throughout the movie. The deliberately dark and shabby lighting is to express how corrupt and depressing city life is. The fact the city is anonymous could prompt many people to name it themselves, New York, Los Angeles its left up to the viewer, or perhaps the movie is saying many cities are like this around the world. The film goes totally against the thriller cliche. The film throws away the modern day thriller rule book and makes its own rules where the good guy doesn't always win and the bad guy doesn't necessarily get caught. In Seven, John Doe is the killer, a bland, ordinary looking guy, with a bland ordinary name, but thats the point, murderers aren't necessarily monsters they're just everyday people like you and me. The idea of the movie is that in a world this corrupt, anyone is capable of murder and sin. This film does more than just give the usual tale of police chasing killer, it gives a film makers representation of modern living, and shows all the possible evils lurking inside it.

Title: Nice Movie
Review:
It's time for Detective Lt. William Somerset (Morgan Freeman) to retire. A young detective named David Mills (Brad Pitt) is teamed up with him. They work together to find a serial killer who has been using the seven deadly sins to commit his crimes. Tracy (Gwyneth Paltrow), Mills' wife, is very depressed and fears for his life.

Depressing and dark, but fascinating at the same time. Fincher shoots the entire film in dim light and shows us the mutilated bodies of his victims. Considering the subject matter, the grimness of the tone wears you down. There is no humor either. The ending is truly harrowing. They (wisely) decided not to write a happy ending. Pitt and Freeman work well together and both give excellent performances. Paltrow (who I hate) was even good! In a small role, Kevin Spacey is very good as well.

Stay away from this movie if you are sensitive to blood, gore, or disturbing content. Watch it if you can handle that. Although it's depressing and unpleasant, it's riveting.

Title: The Best Thriller I've Ever Seen
Review:
I recently watched the movie Se7en and I have to say, I was thoroughly impressed. The film is directed by David Fincher and it is a crime thriller that follows two detectives as they attempt to track down a serial killer who only kills on the seventh day of each month.

The story is gripping from the very beginning, with the film's opening sequence drawing you in and setting the tone for the rest of the movie. The pacing is spot on, with the tension building up throughout the film, leading to an intense and satisfying climax.

The performances in the movie were outstanding, with Morgan Freeman and Brad Pitt delivering powerful and nuanced performances as the two detectives. Their chemistry on screen was great, and their interactions were the highlights of the film.

The film's cinematography was also noteworthy. The use of color and lighting was stunning, creating a sense of unease and tension that perfectly matched the tone of the movie. The film's score was also great, adding to the tension and atmosphere of the film.

Overall, Se7en is a masterfully crafted crime thriller that kept me on the edge of my seat from start to finish. The story is gripping, the performances are outstanding, and the film's technical aspects are top-notch. I highly recommend this film to fans of the genre, and I believe it will be remembered as a classic in the years to come.

Title: increasingly
Review: The film seems to be just showing the world that human nature has fallen and guilty people will be punished. This kind of film has a moral admonition and a sense of warning, which may make people reflect on whether they are guilty after watching it. However, the film does not seem to provide a clear explanation for what causes these people to commit crimes and make the perpetrators unbearable and punish them through killing in the name of God. Is it because of a lack of faith? In the West, the Enlightenment discovered reason, and from then on, reason was gradually pushed to its supreme position. People's self-awareness continued to expand, fully affirming human reason and beginning to despise God. In modern times, rationality centered around science and technology has destroyed the spirit of religious beliefs, and humans who believe that science and technology are omnipotent believe that rationality can achieve everything. It is true that rationality, represented by science, has indeed driven the rapid progress of Western society and facilitated its modernization process. However, rationality has increasingly become a shackle that binds people to themselves. According to Zimmer's view, the development of society increasingly relies on "rationalizations" such as efficiency, computation, and punctuality. Such rationalizations are actually a form of "materialization", where money and commercial value become the only yardstick for measuring all values, and relationships between people become increasingly indifferent due to the power of money.

Title: Best Film of the 90's
Review:
I would have to pick Se7en as my favourite film of the 90's. Although very dark and morbid to pick as a favourite film, I choose it as it sums up everything I love about cinema. The script is outstanding from character development to the boldest movie ending in film history. I remember the first time I saw Se7en at the cinema, it was just before the buzz of the plot began to get around. Sitting there enthralled by the opening title sequence, realising this wasnt the usual hollywood fair. It is the ending that will always stick with me though, never before of since have I seen a British audience react in total astonishment to what they had just seen as they walked out of the cinema. Everyone was stunned, including myself. This is what I love about cinema, a series of pictures and sounds on a screen that can reveal all sorts of emotions in people, fantastic.

Title: There's only one David Fincher
Review:
How does he manage it?

David Fincher really is the master director of the century. His complete disregard for anything soft is admirable. The chiaroscuro lighting he employs, the choice of Kevin Spacey as John Doe. Oh, magnificent.

But, then again he does this with all his films. See Fight Club and Meat Loaf is Robert Poulson, Micheal Douglas is Nicholas Van Orten in the game. Has David Fincher ever done anything that can not be argued to be a combo of thriller and film noir?

The scenes have become famous. The ending was just a brainwave, although I preferred the unshot ending. I know, shoot me. Countless crime films now use the Se7en inspired opening sequence template. If you haven't already done so, you need to go and see it!

Title: Dramatic, dark, brilliant, and so much more...
Review:
"Se7en" is without a doubt David Fincher's best work. Sure, he also directed "Fight Club" and "The Game", both of which were excellent, but I believe this is Fincher at his best. While "Se7en" didn't have the en masse popularity and impact that Fight Club had, it was just as raw, just as real, and just as entertaining.

Although it has many upsides, there are several downsides. Number one being that throughout the movie there is quite a bit of gore, but Fincher apparently thought the audience would lose their stomach at the end, and kept what was possibly the most impactful 'gore' scene hidden, and left it to the imagination of the viewer.

Brad Pitt and Morgan Freeman played off of each other remarkably well, considering how different they, and their characters Mills & Somerset, are. Freeman put on the excellent performance that everyone knows he's capable of, and Pitt was just as good. Kevin Spacey was perfectly cast as "John Doe" because he, quite frankly, creeped me out. Moreso even then Anthony Hopkins as "Hannibal Lecter" in "The Silence of The Lambs".

The best element of the movie, however, was Fincher's extraordinary use of the world around the characters. The raw colors, the amazing sound, and the non-main characters all made the movie feel as if it was real, and made it that much darker when the "climax" occured.

All in all, "Se7en" is, in my opinion, the best serial-killer based movie since "The Silence of The Lambs". Definitely one for any fan of dark mysteries to see, if they can stomach it.

Title: An excellent thought provoker on the value and morality of capital punishment.
Review:
Detective Lt. William Somerset (Morgan Freeman) is about to retire. He is teamed up with a young new detective David Mills (Brad Pitt). Together they try to find a serial killer who uses the seven deadly sins as his M.O. Meanwhile Mills' wife Tracy (Gwyneth Paltrow) fears for her husband's life and is very depressed.

Dark and depressing but just fascinating. Director David Fincher shots the entire film in dim light and shoves the victims mutilated bodies in our face. The grimness of the tone wears you down but that's appropriate considering the subject matter. No humor either. It all leads to a truly harrowing ending. There was supposed to be a happy ending but they (wisely) chose not to do it. Freeman and Pitt work very well together and both give excellent performances. I even thought Paltrow (who I hate) was good! Kevin Spacey is very good too in a small role.

If you have trouble with blood, gore and disturbing subject matter stay far away from this movie. But if you can handle that, watch this one. It's depressing and unpleasant but riveting.

Title: Perfect Writing, Directing, Acting
Review:
Andrew Kevin Walker wrote what could be considered one of the greatest scripts in cinema history and it was undoubtedly adapted with perfect precision by the great auteur David Fincher. The cinematography is also dynamic and gritty, a characteristic found in many Fincher films such as Fight Club.

Easily, the best performance goes to Kevin Spacey. He was the best actor within the group. But I would point to Andrew Kevin Walker again, as he created and actor proof character, but Spacey delivered. If the character himself had had more screen time, I think he would have been just as, if not more interesting to watch than Anthony Hopkins Hannibal.

I've read that Pitt turned down a role in Apollo 13 to do this and a brilliant choice it was. He has since worked with Fincher on Fight Club and The Curious Case Of Benjamin Button, so they must work well together, either way it comes across well on screen.

Title: Arguably the best Crime Thriller ever, certainly of the 90's.
Review:
David Fincher's Se7en is arguably the best crime thriller ever and certainly of the 90's. A meandering investigative story we follow two detectives, Morgan Freeman and Brad Pitt, through their trials to catch a serial killer with a message.

This film really captures the gritty and dirty side of our current culture, exploring an incredibly intelligent, intense and well thought out series of murders.

Se7en, shot by Darius Khondji ASC, is a modern cinematic masterpiece with cinematography that is compelling and tireless.

The story keeps you excited and wanting more, a thoroughly intense 2 hours which you will be going back for more even though the grim subject and imagery. This film is a must watch, one that deserves it't place in the best films of all time.

Title: "Become Wrath"
Review:
"Se7en" is a sinister, bleak and disturbing look at the evil which breathes under the city. It goes without questioning that Se7en is absolutely flawless, a perfect film in every single aspect. The beautiful cinematography, tight editing, moody direction and the strong acting abilities from Brad Pitt, Morgan Freeman and Kevin Spacey.

Some of the murders based on the Seven Deadly Sins are quite gruesome and not for the faint hearted. They don't hold back on showing us the skinny here, folks! The most impressive and memorable part of the film has to be the ending, which is one of the greatest endings ever. It trails along oodles of tension and a very well done conversation in the police car involving Pitt, Freeman and John Doe. It will certainly leave you shocked in your seat.

It also has to be said that John Doe, the man responsible for the murders, will go down as one of the greatest villans in film history... Ta-ta indeed, Hannibal Lecter. The film itself should also go down in film history as the second greatest thriller, taking a seat right behind The Silence of the Lambs.

Title: Greatest most gripping crime movie ever...
Review:
It starts out with a single gruesome murder which then leads to a series of murders all pointing to a psychotic killer that keeps the cops always one step behind. The murderer is trying to leave a lasting impression to the world by making examples of those who have broken the 7 deadly sins, it is up to Morgan Freeman and Brad Pitt to end the crimes before he gets to number 7. The intelligent writing and amazing acting create the most memorable crime movie ever. Morgan Freeman is brilliant, and Brad Pitt fits easily into the hot new rookie cop role. With a battle of personalities to go along with the diabolical criminal mind commiting the murders, the movie keeps you guessing and surprised with each twist and turn. The most chilling scene of the entire movie is the end sequence that will surprise and shock every viewer. A must see for any movie fan, just make sure you have the stomach to handle the very gruesome scenes.

10 out of 10.

Title: Very disturbing, very dark, but very well done.
Review:
Detective Lt. William Somerset (Morgan Freeman) is about to retire. He is teamed up with a young new detective David Mills (Brad Pitt). Together they try to find a serial killer who uses the seven deadly sins as his M.O. Meanwhile Mills' wife Tracy (Gwyneth Paltrow) fears for her husband's life and is very depressed.

Dark and depressing but just fascinating. Director David Fincher shots the entire film in dim light and shoves the victims mutilated bodies in our face. The grimness of the tone wears you down but that's appropriate considering the subject matter. No humor either. It all leads to a truly harrowing ending. There was supposed to be a happy ending but they (wisely) chose not to do it. Freeman and Pitt work very well together and both give excellent performances. I even thought Paltrow (who I hate) was good! Kevin Spacey is very good too in a small role.

If you have trouble with blood, gore and disturbing subject matter stay far away from this movie. But if you can handle that, watch this one. It's depressing and unpleasant but riveting.

Title: £3.99 DVD from virgin, its a disgrace...
Review:
I brought this film from virgin mega-stores not to long ago, for £3.99... I had heard that it was a classic horror/thriller of the 90's so i brought it. I went home and watched it that night to find one of the best movies I have ever seen. you should go out and buy it for a lot more than that,(but don't because you know that the second you do you'll turn around and see it for cheaper and then hate yourself for being impatient.)

I had also heard that it was gratuitously gory and violent, upon watching the film i was pleasantly surprised. In my opinion violence can be used to great effect, and also ,in my experience, films that have been certified '18' because of their violence are often over the top and unnecessary. For example 'Kill Bill' although I found it entertaining (to a point) you start to think that no character in the films life is important because they are being disembowelled left, right and centre, and as soon as you take that away, you take away the reality of it, because in real life every life matters and you cannot just chop through 88 people with a samurai sword. So i thought that this may perhaps be the case for Seven. I was, however, wrong. at points David Fincher used extreme violence but it works well and makes the audience root even more for Mills(Pitt) and Somerset(Freeman) because you want them to solve the crime and be done with this disgusting world (Morgan Freeman is retiring after the case, and Brad Pitt's wife wants to go back to the city they recently moved from).

Another great thing about Seven is that not only does it thrill and disturb but it also makes you question the world that we live in. The film is set in the modern day, but in no particular place. It is a dark and grim city filled with crime and corruption, and it makes the audience really think about crime, helped along by Morgan Freemen who often talks about whether or not crime will stop, or will it go on for ever and why.

The acting is brilliant, the contrast between Mills and Somerset, Somerset being the old, experienced cop on the verge of retirement and Mills, the hot-headed rookie. One of my favourite parts is when Morgan Freeman tells Pitt he should read up on the crimes, and gives him a list of books to get. Later we see a policeman handing the revision notes versions of the books (including 'Dante's Inferno') to Pitt. Kevin Spacy plays 'the bad guy' fantastically, a calm slimy, religious fanatic, who's voice makes you want to turn the TV off and stop watching. The end sequence is very emotional and the tension is increased by a ten minute long car journey with the two heroes in front and Kevin Spacy in the back cleverly named John Doe, the police slang for an unidentified body.

This is an amazing film, scary, tense thought provoking and even funny at times, definitely a classic, and if you have £3.99 i know what i'd spend it on...

Title: this is a true horror film
Review:
I've seen many horror films. This was the first horror film that I could say I truly say it presented true horror. The ugly awful horror that you may feel and experience from a really bad recurring nightmare that makes you fear going to sleep. Or the hopeless, despairing, painful horror you may feel as you witness the death of multiple innocents, like watching the Twin Towers collapsing on 9-11 on live TV. This film while done as a detective story grabs the viewer and thrusts them into what I can only describe as a travelogue through several layers of hell.

Other horror films may try to scare you(Jaws), shock you(Psycho), gross you out(The Fly), or use any number of ways to make you afraid. This is the first movie that made me feel true horror. Not just fear, but that sense of dread and despair that haunts your memories and makes you desperately wish it never happened.

The climatic scene, the opening of the box, is one of the strongest scenes of fictional horror put to film. And if fear and horror is one of the strongest human emotions, then this is one of the most memorable films ever made.

Great movie......................................................................

Title: amazing
Review:
so much amazing i love the ending of this great movie The film's screenplay was influenced by the time Walker spent in New York City trying to make it as a writer. Principal photography took place in Los Angeles, with the last scene filmed near Lancaster, California. The film's budget was US$33 million.

Released on September 22, 1995 by New Line Cinema, Seven went on to become the seventh-highest-grossing film of the year, grossing over $327 million worldwide.[2] It was well received by critics, who praised the darkness and brutality of the film and its themes. The film was nominated for Best Film Editing at the 68th Academy Awards, but lost out to Apollo 13.

Title: David Fincher's Magnum Opus
Review:
I take a very middle-of-the-road stance on this movie, despite the high rating. To me, those who call it genius, unprecedented, etc. are misunderstanding it just as much as those who think of it as lowbrow horror and violence (which makes no sense by the way, as there is almost no violence shown the entire movie, part of what makes it more effective). The goal as I see it was to take the detective genre and turn it inside-out. Use every convention they could and somehow make it original while mixing in the pessimism and cynicism Fincher is deservedly famous for. Thus, by definition it can't be "unprecedented." But to me, doing one simple thing nearly perfect is a great deal more satisfying than trying to do something genius badly. One of the best films since its release by far, and I'm sorry but Fight Club just can't match it. To see the work of the most talented directors of our generation, look no further.

Title: On your toes
Review:
I rewatched this movie after a long time. And out of all the gazillions of movies I have rewatched, Se7en is probably the finest. The suspense is almost laughable how much it makes sense, but when it hits you its like a crescendo to a grand opera, its like that Missile that you see coming towards you and you cannot do nothing about it. Everything comes full circle, the characters, the side characters, the interpersonal relationships, the faces, the traumas. Brad Pitt proves here that he is more than a Pretty face and a damn fine actor. Morgan Freeman is the voice of reason. And last but not the least, Spacey is THE perfect casting. Even if the movie has probably been spoiled for the most of you, it still has the redeeming value in second watching unlike Spacey's other Suspense ( see Usual Suspects ). Seven is one of the greatest movies of all time. And certainly a standout among crime thrillers. It is dark, brooding, has no levity, demands attention and is unmistakably David Fincher. This is his Dark Side of the Moon. A Bonafide Masterpiece.

Title: Exciting till the last minute!
Review: From David Fincher, Se7en is a compelling and brilliant postmodern film noir. It is grim and disturbing but it is also very intelligent and daring. What I did love about Se7en especially is that it is incredibly stylish, beautiful dark cinematography and dazzling landscapes really do add to the atmosphere. Very little of the murders are shown but we are appalled and shocked by what we hear of them, the action is tense and the climax is shattering. There is also an intelligent screenplay, a clever plot telling of a vicious serial killer who murders his victims in a gruesome way to atone for the sins(gluttony, greed, sloth, lust, pride, envy and wrath)he deems them to have committed and excellent direction. The acting is also superb, Morgan Freeman gives another brilliant performance as the disillusioned detective and Brad Pitt is great as Mills in a more meatier role than he has ever done. Gwyneth Paltrow makes a small yet significant appearance as Mill's uneasy wife, while Kevin Spacey superbly delivers equally superb dialogue as John Doe despite the fact he isn't in the film much. Overall, a brilliant film, with adept performances, direction, style and ambition.

Title: Masterpiece
Review:
I gave this film a 9 because no film is perfect. I am an actor so I often study other actors works in various stages of their careers.

To the best of my knowledge, Brad Pitt was not originally cast in his role but was very hungry to break out as a star and thus tried very hard in this role. I love his demeanor as contrasted against Morgan freeman's character.

I recommend this film for any young actor who wants to see how working together closely with another actor builds BOTH actors' skill-sets.

Brad Pitt had a tendency to "over-act" early in his career, but not here. The film is somewhat dark but that just adds to the element of the plot.

All in all, I'd say it's a great film for a date night, or even for a small group of friends watching on a projector in the backyard on a warm summer night.

Title: A thrill through and through

One of the most memorable psychological-thrillers to date and one every movie of the genre should aim to be. Within this genre I would give it a 10/10.

Title: An amazing mystery film that will keep you entralled and disturbed to the very end.
Review:
A major issue with watching lots of horror and dark mystery films is that disturbing imagery tends to lose its effect on you. All the blood and gore just stops being disturbing because you've learned how to look at it and see nothing more than CGI or some cheesy effects. What's amazing about Se7en though is its ability to get around that.

This movie is disturbing. It's hard to go into detail without spoiling the plot, but what I can say is that is shows just enough of the antagonist's murders that you're able to understand the horror of each death. And while what you see is uncomfortable and disgusting, it's nothing compared to what you don't see. The parts of the corpses the movie either jumps-cuts around, or just flat out doesn't show, are the most brutal sections. And since you never see them in great detail, all you're left with is whatever your mind creates to fill in the blanks.

The grizzly murders aren't what make the movie though, as acting is a big part of it too. Brad Pitt and Morgan Freeman make for an amazing pair, pulling off their contrasting character brilliantly. While the "genius detective who wants to leave the force" and the "guided by his emotions" characters aren't anything new, they're pulled off so well you'll fall in love with them both very quickly.

And then we have the plot of the film. The story follows detective Mills and Somerset as they track down a killer who is replicating the Seven Deadly Sins through their murders. While most of the run time is the characters talking about how horrific the case is, shouting about how they'll catch the killer, or standing in the rain; the grizzly atmosphere of the mystery is portrayed perfectly in each scene. It never once feels like the movie diverted away from the intriguing plot line, even in the scenes that have nothing to do with the case are overshadowed by the brutal killings. And of course we have the famous final scene. I won't go into any detail, but the end of the film is a jaw dropping experience, and creates a memorable end to the story.

One big criticism I do have with the film is there are quite a bit of plot holes throughout. Thinking about the killer's plan for more than a few seconds will lead to many questions about it that don't seem to make sense. But in the end, the genius directing and acting make up for these faults. Truly an amazing experience.

Title: A trash story carried by performances
Review:
I'm going to keep this review short because, as it might surprise you, there is absolutely nothing special about this film worth mentioning.

It's your usual, run-of-the-mill block-buster with great (even amazing) actors, and maybe some role-defining performances. However, that is a matter of budget, and does not make a good film.

With all the hype surrounding this movie and the build-up (which takes about 1 hour 55 minutes out of a total of about 2 hours), watching it is incredibly disappointing. The story makes no sense to any sensible human being, and it has so many holes that it's barely enjoyable.

Shocking for the sake of it, 7/10

Title: Se7en is a film you can always watch again, and again!
Review:
Se7en is a mid 90's film with that more rustic picture that we all know very familiarly. The scenes are mostly shot in a darker shade and the transitions are meant to consistently perpetuate a certain ambiance.

What starts out as a classic thriller with detectives being assigned together, despite each others wishes, turns into a gargantuan thriller as well as a life lesson. The life lesson of course is the wisdom to also listen to those with experience, but those with experience also sometimes need to make sure they do not trap themselves inside a specific mindset that otherwise puts blinders on them. The tale is one of cat an mouse, but one that can make you almost agreeable to the killer, to some extent. You're constantly rooting for the good guys while still wondering who we are even chasing.

Through great casting, with remarkable talent, married with an outstanding director vision and on point soundtrack, this film is a product of outstanding entertainment. It's a film that can be watched again and again and you'll always be engaged and fully pulled in. Through the chases, the dark scenes, the self inflicting doubt and mounding questions, this film does not disappoint.

Title: "Se7en one of the best films of the 90s"
Review:
Seven (1995) a dark, suspenseful, mystery, thriller. You feel very uneasy watching this film but also so drawn to it. It stars Brad Pitt, Morgan Freeman, Kevin Spacey and Gwyneth Paltrow. The setting is in an unknown city which is visually dark and gloomy, this is shown by a constant grey mist and rain. A rookie cop (Brad Pitt) moves to a hell hole of a city where a serial kill (Kevin Spacey) starts a string of murders over the course of seven days. Veteran cop (Morgan Freeman) who is meant to be retiring at the end of the seven days is also brought in on the case.They work together to solve the first five murders but at the of the film John Doe ( The name of the serial killer) reveals his true plan which leaves the audience shell shocked. This film is a must watch, I would definitely recommend for anybody that is somewhat interested in films.

Title: In choice of being human or not

Title: Superb
Review:
"Se7en" (pronounce as Seven), is a crime/mystery thriller of the highest caliber. What I love most about this glorious film is the marvelous way in which the story unfolds. It borrows so much from detective films of the past and yet it does something altogether new and unseen. Watching this, it is quite easy to tell that the filmmakers really knew what they were doing. Every step of the way is pure suspense; pure thrills!

Title: its own aesthetic
Review:
That certain noir feel, tweaked so perfectly, keeps all the richness of noir and loses the period specific dialogue that makes classic noir films often feel like cultural artifacts rather than immediately engaging stories that entertain on their own intrinsic merits. Death by sin: gluttonous guy eats too much, lustful guy sexes one too many times, and so on and so on. It's noir without being simply a movie about movies, without simply being an homage to other moviesit stands on its own, it has its own aesthetic, it's just that that aesthetic captures the spirit of luxurious mystery that is associated by film lovers with film noir. Death by sin: gluttonous guy eats too much, lustful guy sexes one too many times, and so on and so on.
